metadata.synopsis: Default Dialogue - the conversation you can have with Minthara at any thime when she's a member of your party. You can ask her about herself, or events that you've experienced together during your adventures. Her responses to you may differ based on some of the choices you make after she joins. Provided you don't betray her for another, she will continue to stand by you, revelling in the violence that follows.

75.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
75.text: He is rather fond of himself. If he truly intends to be the saviour of Baldur's Gate, perhaps he has reason to be.
75.context: NodeContext: thoughtful - talking about Gortash, one of the primary villains, who is acting as a dictator in Baldur's Gate

132.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
132.text: He is rather fond of himself. If he truly intends to be the saviour of Baldur's Gate, perhaps he has reason to be.
132.context: NodeContext: thoughtful - talking about Gortash, one of the primary villains, who is acting as a dictator in Baldur's Gate

183.speaker: Player
183.text: He won't save the city. We will.
183.context: NodeContext: thinking of her background as a villain - she doesn't trust the surface world to ever see her as otherwise. contemptuous of this rather than sad

302.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
302.text: Even if I personally faced down the Army of the Absolute, and drove it from the city single-handedly, I would not be welcomed as a saviour.
302.context: NodeContext: thinking of her background as a villain - she doesn't trust the surface world to ever see her as otherwise. contemptuous of this rather than sad

22.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
22.text: No matter what I do, the people of Baldur's Gate will always see me as an enemy.
22.context: NodeContext: thinking of her background as a villain - she doesn't trust the surface world to ever see her as otherwise. contemptuous of this rather than sad

206.speaker: Player
206.text: They once had a Bhaalspawn as a duke - I'm sure they can tolerate you.

323.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
323.text: I do not want to be tolerated, I want to be feared. Don't you?

93.speaker: Player
93.text: Do you want to be their saviour?
93.context: NodeContext: talknig about being a saviour to the city, and then moving on to conquering it afterwards

321.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
321.text: From the cult and the illithids? Of course. And then I suspect I want exactly what Gortash wants.
321.context: NodeContext: talknig about being a saviour to the city, and then moving on to conquering it afterwards

122.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
122.text: To be feared. Isn't that what you want?
122.context: NodeContext: talking about what she wants

119.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
119.text: When we have all three Netherstones and control the elder brain, all of Faerûn will have reason to fear us.

304.speaker: Player
304.context: NodeContext: annoyed to be the 'lesser of several evils'. She wants to be the prime evil.

297.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
297.text: Yes they would. But I am the lesser of several evils, for now at least. I want more - don't you?
297.context: NodeContext: annoyed to be the 'lesser of several evils'. She wants to be the prime evil.

14.speaker: Player
14.context: NodeContext: talking about the citizens of Baldur's Gate and how little theri opinion of her matters

300.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
300.text: I agree. What matters is that they respect us... and fear us.
300.context: NodeContext: talking about the citizens of Baldur's Gate and how little theri opinion of her matters

156.speaker: Player
156.text: Gortash is no saviour - he's a tyrant.
156.context: NodeContext: dismissive of the player's claim that Gortash is bad for Baldur's Gate

159.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
159.text: Was Baldur's Gate enjoying a golden age of prosperity and peace before Gortash rose to power? I think not.
159.context: NodeContext: dismissive of the player's claim that Gortash is bad for Baldur's Gate

48.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
48.text: This city is like a wild beast. It needs a strong hand to choke it into obedience.
48.context: NodeContext: speaking about Baldur's Gate, disrespectful

141.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
141.text: Gortash may have that strength, but he chose the wrong allies to rule alongside him.
141.context: NodeContext:  talking about Gortash, one of the primary villains, who is acting as a dictator in Baldur's Gate

23.speaker: Player
23.text: The greatest threat to the city is the elder brain that Gortash unleashed.
23.context: NodeContext:  talking about Gortash, one of the primary villains, who is acting as a dictator in Baldur's Gate

40.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
40.text: True. His mistake was choosing the wrong allies.
40.context: NodeContext:  talking about Gortash, one of the primary villains, who is acting as a dictator in Baldur's Gate

277.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
277.text: Ketheric was reliant on his god instead of his own strength, and Orin does not understand power and control. Only blood.
277.context: NodeContext: talking about the flaws of the villains, analytical

83.speaker: Player
83.text: A man who chooses his allies so poorly cannot be trusted to rule.
83.context: NodeContext: with a smile on the last phrase - she's referring to herself as the 'allies'

160.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
160.text: Perhaps you should rule in his place. Your choice of allies is exemplary, after all.
160.context: NodeContext: with a smile on the last phrase - she's referring to herself as the 'allies'

90.speaker: Player
90.text: We would make better allies than Ketheric and Orin.
90.context: NodeContext: talking about Gortash, one of the primary villains, who is acting as a dictator in Baldur's Gate

144.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
144.text: I am reluctant to share power, but if he is amenable to it, an alliance with Gortash may be beneficial.
144.context: NodeContext: talking about Gortash, one of the primary villains, who is acting as a dictator in Baldur's Gate

222.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
222.text: Together, we can teach this city to fear us, and that is just the beginning.

149.speaker: Player
149.text: Gortash is just another obstacle in our path. We will kill him.
149.context: NodeContext: talking about Gortash, one of the primary villains, who is acting as a dictator in Baldur's Gate

113.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
113.text: Given his position in the city's power structure that may be easier said than done. I advocate for caution.
113.context: NodeContext: talking about Gortash, one of the primary villains, who is acting as a dictator in Baldur's Gate

78.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
78.text: I was the Absolute's dagger. I remember every throat that it held me to, and every drop of blood it forced me to spill.
78.context: NodeContext: reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind, thoughtful

239.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
239.text: I was the Absolute's dagger. I remember every throat that it held me to, and every drop of blood it forced me to spill.
239.context: NodeContext: reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind, thoughtful

212.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
212.text: I take no responsibility for the lives I took. I did nothing in the Absolute's name - I was merely a weapon that it wielded.
212.context: NodeContext: reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind, thoughtful

95.speaker: Player
95.text: I remember the Grove. You seemed to enjoy taking all those lives.
95.context: NodeContext: reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind, analysing her thoughts

224.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
224.text: The tadpole... the Absolute... they work together like a drug. I did not feel I was compelled to act against my will, I felt ecstatic to serve.
224.context: NodeContext: reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind, analysing her thoughts

66.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
66.text: Every action seemed a deliberate choice - the best choice - even though I could no more have resisted its commands than flesh can resist decay.
66.context: NodeContext: reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind, analysing her thoughts

232.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
232.text: Even rational minds like ours cannot reject such a powerful influence.
232.context: NodeContext: reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind,

152.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
152.text: The Absolute can make the impossible seem inevitable.
152.context: NodeContext: reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind,

161.speaker: Player
161.text: You should take responsibility for your actions.
161.context: NodeContext: annoyed, reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind,

191.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
191.context: NodeContext: annoyed, reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind,

157.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
157.text: You have been protected from the worst of the Absolute's influence. Understanding what was done to me is beyond you.
157.context: NodeContext: annoyed, reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind,

11.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
11.text: And I do not need lectures on responsibility from somebody who does not know their own mind.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: To lose your free will, and be forced to kill. That must be horrible.
85.context: NodeContext: with a shudder, reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind,

99.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
99.text: I would rather die than endure it again.
99.context: NodeContext: with a shudder, reflecting on what she did while the cult controlled her mind,

292.speaker: Player
292.text: I've lost control of myself before - I hate it.
292.context: NodeContext: talking to a fellow survivor of a cult's brainwashing

36.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
36.context: NodeContext: talking to a fellow survivor of a cult's brainwashing

126.speaker: Player
126.text: I find it liberating to lose control, and surrender myself to my urges.
126.context: NodeContext: concerned, speaking to someone who just admitted they lose control of their urges

27.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
27.text: I had hoped my influence would help tame your chaotic mind. It appears not.
27.context: NodeContext: concerned, speaking to someone who just admitted they lose control of their urges

73.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
73.text: A disturbing admission. I would rather die than lose control of myself again.
73.context: NodeContext: concerned, speaking to someone who just admitted they lose control of their urges

102.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
102.context: NodeContext: surprised - talking about Menzoberranzan, her home city

33.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
33.context: NodeContext: surprised - talking about Menzoberranzan, her home city

189.speaker: Player
189.text: I was born there - but I suspect your life was very different to mine.

306.speaker: Player
306.text: I was born there - I'm surprised we never crossed paths.

151.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
151.text: You are of aristocratic blood? I thought as much.

173.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
173.text: But whatever House matron you sprang from, your upbringing cannot compare with mine.

198.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
198.text: I am a Baenre, born into the city's most ancient and powerful house. My life was one of privilege and danger.

268.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
268.text: Like you, I lived in Qu'ellarz'orl, high above the city's sprawl.

170.speaker: Player
170.text: No, but I have always wanted to.

13.speaker: Player
13.text: I wouldn't want to. It sounds like a terrible place.

296.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
296.text: From the still, dark waters of Lake Donigarten to the black academies of Tier Breche, it is a city of wonders... and terror.
296.context: NodeContext: don-knee-garten (like garden). TEER bresh. talking of her home city, Menzoberranzan

233.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
233.text: But it is not my home anymore. If I were to return, I would be denied all of its wonders, and shown only the terror.
233.context: NodeContext: sadly,talking of her home city, Menzoberranzan

146.speaker: Player
146.text: What was your life like there?
146.context: NodeContext: with pride and a little sadness, talking of her home city, Menzoberranzan

19.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
19.text: I am a daughter of Menzoberranzan's most ancient and powerful House, the Baenre. I lived a life of privilege and danger.
19.context: NodeContext: with pride and a little sadness, talking of her home city, Menzoberranzan

147.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
147.text: My home was at the tallest point of Qu'ellarz'orl, the Place of the Nobles, a plateau high above the city's sprawl.
147.context: NodeContext: kwell-uz-ALL (literally, place of nobles). With pride and a little sadness, talking of her home city, Menzoberranzan

208.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
208.text: I enjoyed every luxury, whether harvested in the Underdark or stolen from the surface, and I survived my first assassination attempt while I still suckled at my mother's breast.
208.context: NodeContext: With pride and a little sadness, talking of her exile from her home city, Menzoberranzan

162.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
162.text: I tasted her blood that day. She covered my body with her own, and a blade bit deep into her chest, almost puncturing her heart.
162.context: NodeContext: telling this story of her mother as if it is natural - she is from a very violent culture, and this is not extraordinary to her

91.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
91.text: When I came of age, she tried to take my life herself, and I gave her fresh scars to match those she earned protecting me.
91.context: NodeContext: telling this story of her mother as if it is natural - she is from a very violent culture, and this is not extraordinary to her

58.speaker: Player
58.context: NodeContext: speaking of her mother, with whom she has a complicated relationship. They have tried to kill each other in the past, but there is a grudging respect.

287.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
287.text: I expect so. If the world were to end, I think my mother would survive to rule over the ruins.
287.context: NodeContext: speaking of her mother, with whom she has a complicated relationship. They have tried to kill each other in the past, but there is a grudging respect.

309.speaker: Player
309.text: Little wonder you find it hard to make friends if your own mother tried to kill you.
309.context: NodeContext: speaking of her mother, with whom she has a complicated relationship. They have tried to kill each other in the past, but there is a grudging respect.

253.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
253.text: She taught me to be resilient, and to guard my heart from those who cannot be trusted. Literally and figuratively.
253.context: NodeContext: speaking of her mother, with whom she has a complicated relationship. They have tried to kill each other in the past, but there is a grudging respect.

256.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
256.text: When I choose to let somebody close, I do not do so lightly.

231.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
231.text: That gives a great depth of meaning to the bonds I do share.
231.context: NodeContext: with a little warmth - she's tlaking about the bond with the player

301.speaker: Player
301.text: A dangerous upbringing. It made you strong.

111.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
111.text: Yes. My House trained me to be a soldier in Lolth's service, and my mother showed me how to survive the perils of society.

125.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
125.text: How so? I could have been born a slave, a serf or a jaluk. I had every advantage, and my mother showed me how to survive.

227.speaker: Player
227.text: It is hard to be without a home.
227.context: NodeContext: With pride and a little sadness, talking of her exile from her home city, Menzoberranzan

194.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
194.text: Yes. Particularly when the home was so magnificent.
194.context: NodeContext: With pride and a little sadness, talking of her exile from her home city, Menzoberranzan

219.speaker: Player
219.text: Would you return if you could?
219.context: NodeContext: With pride and a little sadness, , talking of her exile from her home city, Menzoberranzan

168.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
168.text: If you had seen my city's splendour, you would not ask the question. I will miss it until they day I die.
168.context: NodeContext: With pride and a little sadness, , talking of her exile from her home city, Menzoberranzan

283.speaker: Player
283.context: NodeContext: With  sadness, talking of her exile from her home city, Menzoberranzan

25.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
25.text: For my people, to reject Lolth is to reject life. I am apostate, and would be executed.
25.context: NodeContext: With  sadness, talking of her exile from her home city, Menzoberranzan

328.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
328.text: Though I am proud, I prefer exile to death.
328.context: NodeContext: With pride and a little sadness, talking of her exile from her home city, Menzoberranzan

103.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
103.text: I want you as much as I ever did, but our bond is based on ambition as much as affection. I am not sure that our goals still align.
103.context: NodeContext: 'conversion' is said bitterly. She knows now it was an enforced infection, not a religious conversion as she'd previously thought. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

273.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
273.text: I want you as much as I ever did, but our bond is based on ambition as much as affection. I am not sure that our goals still align.

234.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
234.text: We can survive this together, but I want more - I want us to rule together. To master the brain, and to become Absolute.

270.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
270.text: Do you have the courage and conviction to do what is needed when the time comes?

137.speaker: Player
137.text: I won't let you down. Trust me.

153.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
153.text: I do. But I also know that what I am asking of you is not an easy thing.

228.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
228.text: I do. But I also know that what I am asking of you is not an easy thing.

262.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
262.text: When the time comes to take control of the cult, there will only be me and you. Everyone else is expendable.

60.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
60.text: That is how it must be. You cannot think otherwise.

275.text: I cannot. Too often you lack the conviction to make the hard choices.

110.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
110.text: I cannot. Too often you lack the conviction to make the hard choices.

0.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
0.text: Show me your resolve in actions, not words.

331.speaker: Player
331.text: If we come out of this alive - together - surely that's enough?

276.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
276.text: What would we be then? Survivors, with nothing to show for our struggles but trauma and scars?

252.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
252.text: Since Moonrise - since you saved me from the cult - I have made it clear to you what I want.

195.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
195.text: I have been open about my intentions because I cannot work with those I do not trust.

37.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
37.text: And I cannot love those who lack ambition.

30.speaker: Player
30.text: I will do what is right.

5.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
5.text: If you do not feel the heat of my passion, it is because you no longer ignite it.

3.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
3.text: I am not cold when I spill the blood of our enemies, or when I dream of conquest.

143.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
143.text: Be part of those dreams, as you once were, and you will taste my fire again.

112.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
112.text: I fought at his side once, shortly after my conversion. Before the battle, he was everything a general should be - a charismatic leader with a brilliant strategic mind.
112.context: NodeContext: 'conversion' is said bitterly. She knows now it was an enforced infection, not a religious conversion as she'd previously thought. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

179.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
179.text: I fought at his side once, shortly after my conversion. Before the battle, he was everything a general should be - a charismatic leader with a brilliant strategic mind.
179.context: NodeContext: 'conversion' is said bitterly. She knows now it was an enforced infection, not a religious conversion as she'd previously thought. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

214.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
214.text: I fought at his side once, shortly after my conversion. Before the battle, he was everything a general should be - a charismatic leader with a brilliant strategic mind.
214.context: NodeContext: 'conversion' is said bitterly. She knows now it was an enforced infection, not a religious conversion as she'd previously thought. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

72.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
72.text: And when the fighting began, he led his troops from the front and cut through the enemy like a scythe through stalks.
72.context: NodeContext: impressed, almost awe-struck. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

59.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
59.text: Blows and arrows rained down on him, and before long his face was a mask of blood. But he did not fall - he did not even falter.
59.context: NodeContext: impressed, almost awe-struck. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

289.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
289.text: When we won the day, Ketheric's armour was bent and shattered, but his flesh was unmarked.
289.context: NodeContext: impressed, almost awe-struck. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

325.speaker: Player
325.context: NodeContext: impressed, almost awe-struck. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

267.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
267.text: I have lived long enough to know that few things are impossible in this world.
267.context: NodeContext: impressed, almost awe-struck. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

35.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
35.text: Ketheric's power is a rare thing though. I have never seen its like.
35.context: NodeContext: impressed, almost awe-struck. Talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, while he still lives. She knew him, and fought alongside him.

6.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
6.text: There is a connection to this Nighsong of Balthazar's, whatever - or whoever - it might be.
6.context: NodeContext: trying to figure out the source of Ketheric's power - curious, determined

291.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
291.text: We must find it, and destroy it.

138.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
138.text: The necromancer Balthazar is Ketheric's chief advisor. One who has mastery over the dead may well be able to help the living cheat it.
138.context: NodeContext: trying to figure out the source of Ketheric's power - curious, determined

284.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
284.text: He is usually in his laboratory, elbow-deep in offal, or clinging to his master's side. If he left Moonrise, his mission must be urgent.
284.context: NodeContext: trying to figure out the source of Ketheric's power - curious, determined

49.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
49.text: We should ransack his chambers, and see what secrets he keeps for the great General.
49.context: NodeContext: trying to figure out the source of Ketheric's power - curious, determined

114.speaker: Player
114.text: We just need to hit him harder than they did.
114.context: NodeContext: determined, talking of fighting Ketheric.

80.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
80.text: No, we need to hit him smarter. This battle, like most, will be won or lost before the fighting begins.
80.context: NodeContext: determined, talking of fighting Ketheric.

247.speaker: Player
247.context: NodeContext: determined, speaking of fighting Ketheric

286.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
286.text: Every chance once he is stripped of his power.
286.context: NodeContext: determined, speaking of fighting Ketheric

237.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
237.text: A true soul came to my city preaching a message of togetherness, accompanied by two novices.
237.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

15.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
15.text: A true soul came to my city preaching a message of togetherness, accompanied by two novices.
15.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

303.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
303.text: Menzoberranzen is not fertile ground for such messages. I killed them, and hanged their bodies in my garden.
303.context: NodeContext: with a cruel smile - reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

68.speaker: Player
68.text: Decorative corpses. An interesting design choice.
68.context: NodeContext: talking matter-of-factly about hanging corpses in her garden - reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

295.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
295.text: I would have picked prettier corpses if my intentions had been aesthetic. This was a warning against heresy.
295.context: NodeContext: talking matter-of-factly about hanging corpses in her garden - reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

128.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
128.text: I was not content with the warning though. I intended to wage war on their insolent god, and the rest of its followers.
128.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

221.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
221.text: Even as the flesh sagged and sloughed away from their eyeless skulls, their audacity infuriated me. I had to know where they came from.
221.context: NodeContext: talking about corpses of her enemies - reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

84.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
84.text: And whoever sent them was counting on my curiosity overcoming my caution.
84.context: NodeContext:  reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

175.speaker: Player
175.text: You followed their path back to Moonrise?
175.context: NodeContext:  reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

320.speaker: Player
320.text: Do you know who sent them?
320.context: NodeContext:  reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

88.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
88.text: Indeed. A man you know all too well - General Ketheric Thorm.
88.context: NodeContext:  reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

190.speaker: Player
190.text: You should have captured and interrogated them.
190.context: NodeContext: with grim relish, reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

174.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
174.text: In a manner of speaking, I did.
174.context: NodeContext: with grim relish, reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

121.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
121.text: The dead cough up their secrets just as well as the living.
121.context: NodeContext: with grim relish, reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

136.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
136.text: All it took was a simple act of necromancy, and the corpses told me where I needed to strike - Moonrise Towers.
136.context: NodeContext:  reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

81.speaker: Player
81.text: Given how we met, it's safe to say you failed.

100.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
100.text: It is never safe to point out my shortcomings.

251.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
251.text: But in this instance, you are correct. Moonrise is the site of my greatest failure.
251.context: NodeContext: mild regret, and some anger. doesn't like admitting her failures

255.speaker: Player
255.text: You mustn't have struck very hard - the tower is still standing.
255.context: NodeContext: conviction - certain that the party will defeat Ketheric 'the immortal general'

45.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
45.text: Despite Ketheric's best efforts, so are we. And we shall outlast the immortal general, and his tower.
45.context: NodeContext: conviction - certain that the party will defeat Ketheric 'the immortal general'

243.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
243.text: But he had the upper hand when we first met. I was arrogant enough to believe I had the better of him.
243.context: NodeContext: mild regret, and some anger. doesn't like admitting her failures. Reflecting on her first meeting with Ketheric

312.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
312.text: As it turned out, to my shame, I was defeated without even drawing my weapon.
312.context: NodeContext: mild regret, and some anger. doesn't like admitting her failures

230.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
230.text: I came to Moonrise with a retinue of warriors and assassins - the best House Baenre had to offer.
230.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first meeting with Ketheric

281.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
281.text: I expected a battle, but found a fully-laden feast table, and a welcome befitting a house matron.
281.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first meeting with Ketheric

319.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
319.text: Ketheric expected us - expected me - and I fell for his flattery.
319.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first meeting with Ketheric

185.speaker: Player
185.text: Pride can be a great weakness.

96.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
96.text: I recognise my flaws - pride is certainly among them.

322.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
322.text: Ketheric proposed an alliance between Moonrise and Menzoberranzan. I admit, I was captivated by him.
322.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first meeting with Ketheric

310.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
310.text: He invited me to the head of his table, as his guest of honour. I was wary, of course. If I had been in his position, the food would have been poisoned.
310.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first meeting with Ketheric

242.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
242.text: It was not the food I should have been wary of.

271.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
271.text: It was the pale woman at the foot of the table - Orin the Red.
271.context: NodeContext: regret and anxiety - she fears Orin the Red more than anyone else in the world

314.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
314.text: We had barely begun to eat when she spoke for the first time. I only caught one word - my name.

254.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
254.text: Then, quick as lightning, she climbed onto the table, a dagger in each hand, and skipped toward me, slicing the throats out of my men as she passed them.
254.context: NodeContext: regret and anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

31.speaker: Player
31.context: NodeContext: anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

130.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
130.text: If it had been an option, I would have.

279.speaker: Player
279.context: NodeContext: anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

18.speaker: Player
18.context: NodeContext: anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

101.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
101.text: Few things frighten me. Orin is one of them.
101.context: NodeContext: anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

54.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
54.text: Ketheric held me still. His hand on my shoulder, the grip tight enough to crack the bone.
54.context: NodeContext: anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

204.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
204.text: When Orin stood before me, she touched the dagger to my eye, drawing out a tear of blood.
204.context: NodeContext: anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

77.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
77.text: I want this one, she said. Ketheric nodded his permission, and I was taken below.
77.context: NodeContext: 'i want this one' in a near-whisper. Not mimicking Orin, but remembering her words with anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

16.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
16.text: You've seen the horrors of the colony. Orin kept me there for days. She forced me to watch as my men were processed; some for food, others as thralls.
16.context: NodeContext: anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

64.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
64.text: And then she placed the tadpole in my eye herself.
64.context: NodeContext: anxiety - speaking of Orin, who she fears more than anyone else in the world

29.speaker: Player
29.context: NodeContext: regret and sadness - she's being cruel to herself here, suggesting past trauma was deserved

43.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
43.text: I was. I deserved what happened to me, for my passivity, for my weakness. For my pride.
43.context: NodeContext: regret and sadness - she's being cruel to herself here, suggesting past trauma was deserved

246.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
246.text: You know the rest as well as I do. There were massacres before the Grove - religious communities, mostly. Those who refused to convert.
246.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her past with the cult

280.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
280.text: Then there was you, and now there is freedom.
280.context: NodeContext: determination - putting her past behind her, focusing on the futrue

55.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
55.context: NodeContext: relishing the thought - putting her past behind her, focusing on the futrue

71.speaker: Player
71.text: Nobody deserves what you went through.
71.context: NodeContext: regret and sadness - she's being cruel to herself here, suggesting past trauma was deserved

248.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
248.text: I deserved it. I was passive, weak... proud.
248.context: NodeContext: regret and sadness - she's being cruel to herself here, suggesting past trauma was deserved

265.speaker: Player
265.text: Understandable. He gave you the welcome you felt you deserved.
265.context: NodeContext: regret. doesn't like admitting her failures

209.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
209.text: Perhaps I deserved what came after the welcome as well.
209.context: NodeContext: regret. doesn't like admitting her failures

105.speaker: Player
105.text: I'm surprised you were so complacent.
105.context: NodeContext: regret. doesn't like admitting her failures

104.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
104.text: It is a mistake I hope never to repeat.
104.context: NodeContext: regret. doesn't like admitting her failures

316.speaker: Player
316.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first meeting with the cult of the Absolute

201.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
201.text: No. I was prepared for combat, but I intended to strike subtly.
201.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first meeting with the cult of the Absolute

313.speaker: Player
313.text: They were fools to encroach on Lolth's territory.
313.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

97.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
97.text: I thought so too. This world is full of fools, after all.
97.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

241.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
241.text: But in this instance, I was mistaken. Our visitors were not fools - they were bait.
241.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

52.speaker: Player
52.text: Yet they recruited you all the same.
52.context: NodeContext: 'recruited' with a shake of the head. She knows her 'recruitment' was actually brain-washing. reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

56.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
56.text: Recruited. You could call it that. I intended to wage war on their god and the rest of its presumptive followers.
56.context: NodeContext: 'recruited' with a shake of the head. She knows her 'recruitment' was actually brain-washing. reflecting on her first encounter with the cult of the Absolute

278.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
278.context: NodeContext: talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

169.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
169.text: A smaller part than I had hoped.

133.speaker: Player
133.text: Cheer up. It was a good kill.

51.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
51.text: It was. But it has left a bitter taste.

217.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
217.text: Orin could make herself a mirror to anyone she met. A perfect physical replica, down to the slightest blemish or imperfection.

188.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
188.text: It was only the surface that she imitated though. The skin and the muscle and the bone.

4.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
4.text: Peel back the surface, and her madness lay beneath. She could not hide that, no matter what form she took.

269.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
269.text: No matter how perfect the surface imitation, few would see themselves reflected in Orin's madness. In her soul.

67.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
67.text: I did see myself there. A broken version of myself, but recognisable nonetheless.

117.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
117.text: And, of course, you saw yourself there too. She was your sister after all, bound to you by Bhaal's blood.

39.speaker: Player
39.text: I'm nothing like her, and neither are you.

150.speaker: Player
150.text: You're almost as sadistic as she was. You could be part of the family too.

89.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
89.text: Perhaps I will be, one day.

207.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
207.text: Now that you have your father's dark blessing, you are the master of your urges, and together we can win this fight, and become as gods ourselves.

70.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
70.text: When we first met, I could not have chosen that future. I could choose nothing.

177.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
177.text: Your family is a little too cut-throat, even for me, child of Murder. But we can certainly rule together.

186.speaker: Player
186.text: She was driven by the same urges that drive me, but they drove her to madness.

139.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
139.text: I was like her once, when we first met, and before you ever knew me.

236.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
236.text: Oh, but I am. Given what we learned of her mother, I see how similar we truly are.

140.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
140.text: What was I when you first knew me? Before you ever knew me?

154.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
154.text: A madwoman, butchering prey in the name of a god who would discard me without a thought once I was no longer of use.

1.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
1.text: Bhaal, Lolth... the Absolute. They do not have followers - they only have victims, and they reward devotion with death.

28.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
28.text: It is only because of you that I did not meet the same fate as Orin. Lost to madness and blood.

178.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
178.text: If you had killed me when we first met, I would have been just one more casualty of your crusade against the Absolute.

288.speaker: Player
288.text: She was cruel, maniacal, sadistic. You could have been sisters.

86.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
86.text: Given what we learned of Orin's mother, that is painfully accurate.

315.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
315.text: We were both born of trauma, both raised by parents who protected us with one hand and tormented us with the other.

118.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
118.text: That was true, once. When you first knew me, I was no different to Orin.

235.speaker: Player
235.text: Then let's move on to the next part - Gortash.

106.speaker: Player
106.text: Then let's move onto the final part - the elder brain.

142.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
142.text: As you wish. There is little use fretting over spilt blood.

293.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
293.text: I take no pleasure in his passing. Whatever faults he may have had, Ketheric was a great leader.
293.context: NodeContext: talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

184.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
184.text: I take no pleasure in his passing. Whatever faults he may have had, Ketheric was a great leader.
184.context: NodeContext: talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

42.speaker: Player
42.context: NodeContext: surprised she has to explain this - talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

272.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
272.text: Of course. He ruled Moonrise for centuries. That in itself deserves respect.
272.context: NodeContext: surprised she has to explain this - talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

238.speaker: Player
238.text: Any greatness he once had faded  long ago - the man we killed was a bitter old fossil.
238.context: NodeContext: reflecting thoughtfully - talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

180.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
180.text: Life was crueller to him than death. It is no great wonder that he found his strength in Myrkul.
180.context: NodeContext: reflecting thoughtfully - talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

62.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
62.text: I believe he was an honourable man, but the gods used him as their plaything. First, Shar and her sister, then the Three behind the Absolute.
62.context: NodeContext: thoughtful, talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

116.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
116.context: NodeContext: genuine, talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

65.speaker: Player
65.context: NodeContext: thoughtful, dismissing a suggestion she is 'soft-hearted' - talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

32.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
32.text: It is a sharp mind that feels sympathy for one who suffers unnecessarily, not a soft heart.
32.context: NodeContext: thoughtful, dismissing a suggestion she is 'soft-hearted' - talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

163.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
163.text: I saw strength in Ketheric that had been diluted by pain.
163.context: NodeContext: talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

202.speaker: Player
202.text: He doesn't deserve sympathy. He was responsible for his own actions.
202.context: NodeContext: 'as are we' refers to being responsible for actoins. reflecting a little sadly - talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

129.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
129.text: As are we, and if the coming battle breaks us, I hope that someone will mourn our passing despite the bodies we have left in our wake.
129.context: NodeContext: 'as are we' refers to being responsible for actoins. reflecting a little sadly - talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

21.speaker: Player
21.text: Do you think he could have been redeemed?
21.context: NodeContext: talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

250.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
250.text: A meaningless question. If he had killed us, and conquered the Sword Coast, I would envy him.
250.context: NodeContext: talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

264.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
264.text: As it is, he lost, and I pity him.
264.context: NodeContext: talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

176.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
176.text: But I will never forgive him for handing me to Orin. For that, I hope Myrkul hollows out his bones, and lets them be dust.
176.context: NodeContext: vindictive, talking of Ketheric, one of the primary villains, after the party killed him

9.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
9.text: No more than you or I.

305.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
305.text: I am not on edge, I am alert, as you should be too.

298.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
298.text: I am not on edge, I am alert, as you should be too.

107.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
107.text: Orin could be anywhere... could be anyone.

215.speaker: Player
215.text: *Despite her protestations to the contrary, it is clear that Minthara is afraid.*
215.context: NodeContext: vulnerable - Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

165.text: *Despite her protestations to the contrary, it is clear that Minthara is afraid.*
165.context: NodeContext: vulnerable - Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

61.speaker: Narrator
61.text: *Despite her protestations to the contrary, it is clear that Minthara is afraid.*
61.context: NodeContext: vulnerable - Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

53.speaker: Player
53.text: It's ok to be afraid - given Orin's powers it would be madness not to be.
53.context: NodeContext: vulnerable - Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

200.text: If you sense my fear, be sure that she does too. It is her greatest weapon.
200.context: NodeContext: vulnerable - Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

220.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
220.text: If you sense my fear, be sure that she does too. It is her greatest weapon.
220.context: NodeContext: vulnerable - Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

225.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
225.text: She had me in her clutches once before. Promise that you won't let it happen again.
225.context: NodeContext: vulnerable - Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

216.speaker: Player
216.context: NodeContext: reassured - talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

245.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
245.text: Thank you. Together, we will survive her.
245.context: NodeContext: reassured - talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

69.speaker: Player
69.text: You don't need my promise - you can protect yourself.
69.context: NodeContext: doubtful - talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

7.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
7.text: Against Orin? I have my doubts.
7.context: NodeContext: doubtful - talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

240.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
240.text: We need to watch over each other, now more than ever.
240.context: NodeContext: solidarity, trying to reassure herself - talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

41.speaker: Player
41.text: Show some backbone, and don't let her intimidate you.
41.context: NodeContext: insistent, thinks we're in denial - talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

192.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
192.text: I am not intimidated, I am terrified. You should be too.
192.context: NodeContext: insistent, thinks we're in denial - talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

17.speaker: Player
17.text: Orin may frighten you, but not me. I've faced worse.
17.context: NodeContext: Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

197.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
197.text: I doubt it. Her father is murder incarnate, and she is a devoted daughter. To please Bhaal she would butcher the world.
197.context: NodeContext: Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

124.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
124.text: I doubt it. Her father is murder incarnate, and she is a devoted daughter. To please Bhaal she would butcher the world.
124.context: NodeContext: Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

158.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
158.text: She has the scent of our blood, and she wil tease and toy until she tires of the hunt. Then she will obliterate us without a second thought.
158.context: NodeContext: Talking about one of the primary antagonists, Orin, who is a vicious killer now stalking the party. Minthara has history with her, and fears her

76.text: Do not presume to know how I feel.

115.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
115.text: Do not presume to know how I feel.

261.speaker: Player
261.text: Unnerving. What do you suggest we do?
261.context: NodeContext: doing an impression of Orin - creepy voice - she's teasing the player

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Then we'll need to be careful who we trust.
38.context: NodeContext: doing an impression of Orin - creepy voice - she's teasing the player

127.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
127.text: Her aim will be to erode our trust in one another. We cannot let that happen.

167.speaker: Player
167.text: What's to say you're not Orin. Right now.
167.context: NodeContext: doing an impression of Orin - creepy voice - she's teasing the player

8.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
8.text: You see through my Minthara-mask, pretty little flesh-thing.
8.context: NodeContext: doing an impression of Orin - creepy voice - she's teasing the player

324.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
324.text: A joke. I am no more Orin than you are.

120.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
120.text: If she is watching - and she may well be - she will delight in seeing suspicion spread among us so quickly. We cannot let that happen.

20.speaker: Player
20.text: In that case, if anyone acts suspiciously, we kill them. Simple.

63.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
63.text: If we kill every suspicious person in Baldur's Gate, we will have more blood on our hands than Bhaal.

307.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
307.text: Nervous? Don't be preposterous. I am on alert, as you should be too given who hunts us.
307.context: NodeContext: trying to brush off an accusation that she's nervous, unconvincingly

34.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
34.text: Nervous? Don't be preposterous. I am on alert, as you should be too given who hunts us.
34.context: NodeContext: trying to brush off an accusation that she's nervous, unconvincingly

134.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
134.text: I have faced Orin before, and she left scars on me that will never heal. She will enjoy adding to them, and she can strike whenever she pleases.

47.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
47.text: She could be anywhere... could be anyone.
